instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v no power, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I'm working on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board, it has no signs of liquid or physical damage. Customer states computer just turned off by itself. Some info about board:

- Stuck at 5v 0,45A
- LDO's on <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> are not shorted
- <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0V, shorted to groud on system side (diode mode 0,000V)
- <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> 0V, shorted to ground  (diode mode 0,000V)
- <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> are shorted to each other (diode mode 0,000V, 0,000ohm resistance)
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0V, not shorted (diode mode 0,384V)

Is there any sense do dig into this board? I guess CPU got 12V from PPBUS and got fried, right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v no power, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Very likely CPU is fried.
You can lift CPU coils one by one and check if the short from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> disappear.
Then check for short (ohm mode) on CPU rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v no power, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have removed all CPU coils and short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is not gone. 

These are readings on CPU rails (CPU side):

<SIGNAL>PPV095_S0_CPUVCCIO_REG_R</SIGNAL> - 43,0 ohm
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_CPU_R</SIGNAL> - 9,9 ohm
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL>- 2,9 ohm
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> - 2,9 ohm
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> - 2,5 ohm
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> - 2,5 ohm
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_CPU_PH3</SIGNAL> - 2,5 ohm
PPVCCEDRAM_S0_REG_R - 24 ohm
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 3,0 ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v no power, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Then may be just a shorted cap.
Check first no short on other big coils, from the other secondary power supplies.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v no power, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Other coils are not shorted. Caps on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> looks fine, no damages. The only way to find damaged one is to inject voltage and use thermal cam. Is it safe for CPU now to inject voltage to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with all CPU coils removed? Or I should separate <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> somehow (if it's possible..)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v no power, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You've said not same value to ground on CPU coils, as in <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
If you are sure about that, the CPU power supplies are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v no power, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I'm sure about these readings. I have injected safe 2V 2 Amps and foud out, that <CAPACITOR>C6455</CAPACITOR> on  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SPKRAMP_LEFT</SIGNAL> line is glowing on thermal cam like crazy. After removing it <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> are measuring 0,384V in diode mode, so I think case is solved.
